The campaign uses a fake Cloudflare Turnstile CAPTCHA widget requesting a valid business email address, filtering targets. Once the authorization code is pasted onto the malicious page, the attacker gains full access to the Microsoft account.
Articles.threat_actor: Unspecified, but a threat actor using social engineering techniques.
mitre_ttps: T1566.002 - Phishing: Spearphishing Link (social engineering for OAuth flow)
T1534 - Internal Spearphishing
T1078.004 - Valid Accounts: Cloud Accounts (hijacking Microsoft accounts)
T1098.001 - Account Manipulation: Additional Email Address (bypassing MFA)
T1110 - Brute Force (indirectly, by exploiting misconfiguration/trust in OAuth)
Articles.analyse: Critical impact on Microsoft account security, particularly for businesses using Azure CLI. The attack bypasses MFA and does not require a password, making it highly effective. The strategic potential is the theft of access to cloud resources and sensitive data. The difficulty is that the traffic appears legitimate (OAuth flow).
recommandations: Look for unusual Azure CLI login activity, such as logins from new IP addresses.
Monitor for legacy Graph scopes, which attackers intentionally leverage to evade detection.
Educate users about social engineering attacks, especially those involving complex authentication flows or unusual information requests.
Implement conditional access policies and Zero Trust for cloud applications.
Regularly audit OAuth app permissions and access tokens.

Articles.title: Notepad++ fixes flaw that let attackers push malicious update files
Articles.description: Notepad++ released version 8.8.9 to fix a vulnerability in its WinGUp update tool, following user reports that the updater retrieved malicious executables instead of legitimate update packages. This issue, potentially a supply chain attack or network traffic hijacking, allowed the GUP.exe file to spawn an unknown '%Temp%\AutoUpdater.exe' executable, running commands to collect device information. Notepad++ and WinGUp have been hardened to verify the signature and certificate of downloaded installers, aborting the update if verification fails. Organizations in East Asia were reportedly targeted very specifically.
Articles.threat_actor: Sophisticated threat actor with significant resources (capable of hijacking ISP traffic).
mitre_ttps: T1195.002 - Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
T1195.003 - Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Hardware Supply Chain (potential traffic hijacking at ISP level)
T1036.005 - Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location (AutoUpdater.exe)
T1566.001 - Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment (malicious update)
T1082 - System Information Discovery (commands to collect device info)
Articles.analyse: Significant impact on trust in software updates and risk of widespread infection for Notepad++ users. The attack highlights the vulnerability of update mechanisms and attackers' ability to compromise the supply chain or network infrastructures. The apparent targeting in East Asia suggests espionage or competitive advantage motives. The risk was arbitrary code execution and information collection on victims' devices.
recommandations: Upgrade Notepad++ to version 8.8.9 or higher immediately.
Ensure all official binaries and installers are signed with a valid certificate and verify these signatures.
Remove any custom root certificates previously installed if using versions older than v8.8.7.
Implement network security measures to detect and prevent update traffic hijacking (e.g., DNSSEC, SSL/TLS traffic monitoring).
Educate users on verifying the authenticity of software updates.

Articles.title: One newsletter to rule them all (DeadLock ransomware, Brickstorm malware)
Articles.description: Cisco Talos uncovered new TTPs related to DeadLock ransomware, which targets Windows machines with a custom encryption algorithm using time-based cryptographic keys. The actor uses the Bring Your Own Vulnerable Driver (BYOVD) technique with an unknown loader to exploit a Baidu Antivirus driver vulnerability (CVE-2024-51324), enabling EDR process termination. The 'stealthy and resilient' Brickstorm malware is used by China-sponsored actors to achieve long-term persistence in critical infrastructure networks, targeting VMware servers.
Articles.threat_actor: Financially motivated threat actor (DeadLock ransomware), China-sponsored actors (Brickstorm malware).
mitre_ttps: T1070.004 - Indicator Removal on Host: File Deletion
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact (DeadLock Ransomware)
T1562.001 - Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools (EDR termination)
T1543.003 - Create or Modify System Process: Windows Service
T1574.009 - Hijack Execution Flow: Dylib Hijacking (BYOVD)
T1090 - Proxy (Brickstorm for persistence)
T1078 - Valid Accounts (initial access for Brickstorm)
Articles.analyse: High impact on enterprise resilience and critical infrastructure security. DeadLock ransomware uses sophisticated evasion techniques to bypass EDR defenses and complicate recovery. Brickstorm poses a persistent threat to VMware environments, with potential for long-term espionage and disruption of vital services. The geographical potential is global for DeadLock, and targeted at critical infrastructure for Brickstorm, with a particular interest in critical infrastructure networks.
recommandations: Apply patches for all known vulnerabilities, including CVE-2024-51324 and other flaws affecting VMware.
Strengthen EDR defenses and endpoint security solutions to detect and prevent disabling attempts.
Implement strict network segmentation to protect VMware servers and critical infrastructure.
Deploy Snort rules (SIDs 65576, 65575, 301358) and ClamAV detections for DeadLock ransomware.
Monitor post-exploitation activities, especially those aimed at establishing persistence in critical networks.

Articles.title: Palestine Action: Operations and Global Network
Articles.description: The Palestine Action group has intensified its operations globally following its designation as a terrorist organization in the UK in July 2025. This dual-track strategy involves inciting Domestic Violent Extremists (DVEs) outside the UK to increase attacks, while abstaining from major operations within the UK to contest the designation legally. The group's global network uses tactics like vandalism (red paint, blunt instruments), physical obstruction (human chains), and sabotage (damaging assets inside facilities) against defense contractors, militaries, financial services, logistics, and shipping companies perceived to support Israel. The most notable incident was the £7 million damage to RAF Brize Norton aircraft in June 2025.
Articles.threat_actor: Palestine Action (including franchises like Palestina Libera, affiliates like Death to Toll, offshoots like Unity of Fields, and partners like Shut the System).
mitre_ttps: T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service (obstruction)
T1485 - Data Destruction (sabotage)
T1560 - Archive Collected Data
T1078 - Valid Accounts (if breaching facilities)
T1566.002 - Phishing: Spearphishing Link (propaganda/incitement)
Articles.analyse: Significant physical threat to private and public sector facilities in Western Europe, North America, and Australia, particularly those in defense, finance, and logistics. The group's decentralized structure and reliance on DVEs make it adaptable. The increase in operational tempo due to geopolitical events (Israel-Hamas conflict) and the UK designation elevates the risk. The financial impact can be substantial (e.g., millions in damages to RAF aircraft).
recommandations: Enhance physical security measures to deny internal access to facilities, as most costly attacks occurred post-breach.
Implement layered security, including external surveillance, access controls, and rapid response protocols for physical intrusions.
Conduct regular risk assessments for facilities that are potential targets due to perceived links to Israel or defense industries.
Monitor intelligence for DVE activity and specific TTPs promoted by Palestine Action or its affiliates.
Develop and test incident response plans for both physical and cyber attacks, considering the dual nature of these threats.
